Expectation1: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation1: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sat in my small office at the church, the sunlight filtering through stained glass, casting colored patterns on my desk. My calendar reminded me that Mrs. Evans would arrive soon, seeking comfort and guidance for her ongoing grief. As her priest, I knew how much she depended on these conversations, and I felt the weight of her trust. Yet, as a citizen, I was also aware that the free vaccine clinic at the community center was happening this weekend, and volunteers were desperately needed. I had already organized my tax documents, but the call for help at the clinic tugged at my sense of civic duty. I could almost hear the voices—my parishioners expecting my presence and support, my neighbors hoping I’d stand with them in this public health effort. My heart raced as I tried to reconcile these demands, feeling the tension build inside me. I wanted to be everywhere, to serve everyone, but I knew I would have to choose.
